title.narrative: Promoting Women?s Property Rights in Eastern Uganda

description.narrative: The development problem has to do with the oppressive cultural and traditional practices in Uganda that deny women the equal human value given to men and both genders as eligible property owners. Women in the target districts of Jinja and Mayuge are merely recognized as witness to the family land and other property agreements. Men are able to control and benefit from property in this case land.The overall objective is promoting gender equality in women?s property rights so that their implementation is suppo rted in the project area. The project aims at reducing all kinds of inequality among target groups for example between different groups of women in poly- and monogamous marriages. These objectives correspond directly to Finland?s development goals regardin g women?s and girls? rights and women's possibilities to improve their economic independence.The key activities include capacity building and consciousness-raising activities for and together with the beneficiaries on selected themes. These will be enhance d by community dialogues information seminars radio programs and producing information material and supporting women?s financial possibilities for receiving legal aid.The cooperating partners Filantropia and United Religions Initiative Great Lakes (URI-GL) will strengthen their capacity through joint monitoring trips and share their expertise on women?s empowerment. The project will develop already existing structures through the network of formal and informal leadership structures in the project area. Also the partner organization URI-GL?s existing network of local grassroots groups will be developed and new ones created.The project intervention will primarily adopt an integrated approach involving two main groups of beneficiaries. The immediate beneficiari es of the project are the 30 women as Rights Holders and their families as 20 men and 40 Duty Bearers (paralegals formal and informal structures including official cultural and religious leaders). The final beneficiaries also include the general public (2 000 000) in the project area.
